questions.text: Find the limit: \( \lim_{x\to \pi/4} \dfrac{x(1-\tan x)}{\cos x - \sin x} \).
Use the result of (A) to derive an approximation of \sec x in terms of x for values of x near \pi/4.

answers.text:
Rewrite \dfrac{x(1-\tan x)}{\cos x-\sin x}=x\cdot \dfrac{\cos x-\sin x}{\cos x} \cdot \dfrac{1}{\cos x-\sin x}=\dfrac{x}{\cos x}.\
Thus \( \lim_{x\to \pi/4} \dfrac{x(1-\tan x)}{\cos x-\sin x} = \lim_{x\to \pi/4} \dfrac{x}{\cos x} = \dfrac{\pi/4}{\cos(\pi/4)} = \dfrac{\pi/4}{\sqrt{2}/2}= \dfrac{\pi \sqrt{2}}{4}. \)

Near \pi/4, the expression equals approximately \dfrac{x}{\cos x}. From part (A), \dfrac{x}{\cos x} \approx \dfrac{\pi \sqrt{2}}{4}. Solving for \sec x gives \sec x \approx \dfrac{\pi \sqrt{2}}{4x} for x near \pi/4.
